Calendar Reform Could Begin by Next Year
By RICK DILLMAN

After nearly twenty years of discussion
about needed reform it now appears that
Hopkins is on the verge of producing a real
change in its academic calendar.
In the fall of 1968 an Ad Hoc Committee
was established by President Gordon to study
Possible methods of co-ordinating the programs
of the School of Hygiene and Public Health, the
Medical School, and Homewood Campus.
Currently the Medical and Health Institutions
operate on a quarterly schedule while
Homewood uses a semester system. This
situation makes the scheduling of inter-school
classes difficult if not impossible. The purpose
of the Committee was to examine the situation
and recommend a solution which would, in the
words of Chaiiman Dr. William Bevin, "achieve
unity among the different branches of the
University."
Although the Committee will not vote on
thes final draft of the proposal until next
Tuesday, the general outlines and goals are now

WILLIAM WALKER, Hopkins Employee,
who sought to."get the workers together."

By EMIL PAVLOVICS
Despite an increase in minimum
salaries and nearly all other salaries
among university hourly employees, the
custodial workers intent to press their
plans for a grievance committee,
maintained William Walker, an organizer
of the project.
A petition for the formation of a
grievance committee for the custodial
workers is to be presented to the
Whitehead Hall managers today. The
general feeling, as expressed by
Weinbach, is that "We would welcome
such a move, and think it's a very good
idea, though we aren't certain that such
a need exists." The custodians feel that
the committee is a "must," as a
legitimate channel for change and
correction.
Wesley A. Taylor, Plant Manager,
and Joseph Rumberger, Director of
Personnel Services, jointly announced
that, as of February 3, all minimum
salaties were raised from $1.46 perhour
to $1.60 per hour. "Wage reviews are a
continuing process,' Taylor and
Rumberger said, "and it is anticipated
that further raises, on an individual
basis, will be made."
George Weinbach, Assistant to the
Plant Manager, felt that the "raise had
been in the works for quite a while, and
was merely the result of continual
reviews of the situation."

raise was an attempt to stifle the
growing unrest among the univeristy

workers over low wages and unresolved
grievances. The attempt would be futile,
he added, since "our grievances are not
solely in the area of wages; and even the
iwage issue has not been resolved to our

seemed to have been exerted from
Whitehead, and again took the form of
threatened loss of jobs.
It was only when the older
employees saw that Walker was not
being fired for his part in organizing
them that they felt safe enough to sign
the petition.

Hullabaloo
Given New
Constitution
By JACK HOLLIS
A new constitution for the
Hullabaloo, proposed by a Student
Council committee investigating the
yearbook, was approved unanimously
by that legislative body at a meeting last
Monday night.
Joel Crawford, editor-in-chief of
the yearbook, was not consulted in the
preparation of the new constitution. A
new one was needed, according to
Council president Russ Passarella,
because the "old constitution obviously
wasn't being followed" and "something
was drastically wrong."
Embodied in the new constitution
is a limitation on how much the
yearbook may spend. All expenditures
over $50 have to be approved by the
book's Board of Control and the
president of the SAC. This was done
because the last two yearbooks, for the
only time in the history of the
Hullabaloo, lost money. Senior class
funds must make up any deficit
incurred.
Regular Meetings
The document was accepted as
proposed, except for one change in the
rules governing the Board of Control
sessions. The Hullabaloo's officers must
meet weekly during the second semester
and bi-weekly during the first.
Six of the seven-man Board of
Control were accepted by the Student
Council without debate. They are:
Crawford, editor-in-chief; Ken Locker,
photography editor; Roger Moose,
campus editor; Allan Rubeo, business
manager; John Globig, SAC
representative; and Dave Wirtz, senior
class representative.
The appointment of John Adams
as executive editor was protested bY
Crawford, who suggested Joel Ziskin in
his stead. Ziskin is a junior who has
worked for the Hullabaloo, literary
magazine, Baltimore Free Press, and the
News-Letter. His nomination was voted
down 5-3 with five abstentions, and
Adams was accepted. A sophomore
transfer student from Virginia Military
Institute, Adams has worked on
yearbooks at his high school and
previous college. Passarella stated that
"knowledge of how a yearbook is done
is what is important," not length of
attendance at Hopkins. Adams has been
here since September.
"Unconstitutional"
Wording in parts of the
constitution is unclear, in the opinion of
Crawford. The executive editor has been
given total control over the yearbook's
layout, but it is not specified as to
whether the Board of Control or the
editor-in-chief can override his
decisions.
Believing that the Student
Council's action was "unconstitutional
from every aspect," Crawford declared
that the Council was not empowered to
establish a constitution for an
extracurricular activity. He interprets it
as a "purely political move."
In defense of the Council,
president Passarella stated that its
constitution gives it the responsibilitY
for all organizations on campus, a
delegation of power that he contrues to
include supervision over the by-laws of
those organizations. There are no
precedents.
Stating that his power as
editor-in-chief is "non-existent,''
Crawford asserted that "I really have
very little influence with the Board of
Control". In his opinion the future of
the Hullabaloo is very dim. "The 1969
yearbook isn't even going to be worth
reading," he said. According to him, it
will be "a return to the pre-high school
syndrome ...a book without anY,
redeeming artistic content whatsoever:
It will be extremely dull as far as layout
goes."

Non-involvementContinues to PlaguePrograms
By DAVID HOELSCHER
City Editor

Despite the clamor for student
involvement in the community, which developed
at the beginning of last semester, all but a few of
the programs presently in existence at
Homewood are woefully lacking in student
membership and in clear ideas of direction.
There are presently, for example, three tutorial
projects on the Homewood campus and a fourth soon to
appear. Of the three presently "active" programs, one,
the S.A. tutorial project, has 175 students; while the
APO project has five students, and Victor Dates'
program for disadvantaged children now has ten.
Francis Smith, president of APO, argues that he
approaches tutorial projects in a different manner than
the S.A., and, besides, the S.A. has "given us the cold
shoulder." Nevertheless, it does appear from last
semester's activity that there are substantial difficulties
in developing the type of program Smith envisioned.
Basically APO has tried to cultivate a "one-to-one
relationship" between the tutor and the tutee. In
addition to such a relationship, Smith tried to adopt a
"block" tactic attracting ghetto dwellers from the same

area. In this way he hoped to further reduce the
inhibitions to tutoring activities which have occurred in
other projects.
Lick of Time
Unfortunately Smith stated that there was some
difficulty maintaining both the interests of the tutors
and any continuing relationship with the tutees. Few
students had the necessary time to devote to such a
program.
"Because of these difficulties we have to make the
program more relevant and workable,"stated Smith.
APO is not the only campus organization to call
for a "more relevant and workable" program, however.
Michael Amey, president of the Urban Affairs Council,
lamely stated that the UAC has been in a "transitionary
stage" during the last semester, attempting to reorganize
their program. Plans for such "reorganization" are as yet
uncertain.
The difficulties facing APO and the Urban Affairs
Council are characteristic of some but not tall of the
campus programs. Jim Arcibald's AWARE and Jim
Cleary's tutoring program stand out as being notably
more successful. Archibald is presently planning a large
scale recruitment drive for second semester because his
present staff is not able to handle the increased activities
of AWARE.
The differences between AWARE, with seven
speaking engagements for February already confirmed,
and APO and the Urban Affairs Council which are
"seeking more relevant and workable directions" is
striking. Although all groups began the semester with
substantial ideas and the hopes of expanding those ideas
into workable programs, not all were successful. The
Students' Opportunities in the Inner City, for example,
has been cancelled by its chairman, Martin Hickey.
Hickey indicated that the program was unable to draw
student interest or find the necessary information.
The Myth of Student Apathy
As one of the reasons for the organizational
difficulties both Amey and Smith, along with Mike
Rosenberg of the Community Involvement Board cited
student apathy as a major factor in the difficulties their
programs were facing. Smith stated, for example, that
"it is very difficult for undergraduates to get involved,
basically a Hoppy does what the Establishment tells him
to do."
This attitude, although prevelant on Homewood
campus, has little factual support. AWARE has close to
40 students participating in the program and Archibald
is confident that the number can be expanded; S.A.
tutoring has 175 students tutoring and Wickwire hopes

that even that number may be expanded. In all, nearly
10% of the undergraduate body, participates in
Homewood tutoring activities.
S.A. President Joe Weinberg stated that this makes
the Homewood campus one of the more active campuses
in the nation. The major difficulty, therefore, is not in
motivating thes students but in attracting them to
specific projects.
"It isn't so much a question of having a vague
program that you want to do and then asking students
to help you firgure it out," said Archibald,"You have to
be able to present the students with a plan, you have to
be able to tell them what you want to do. If you can't
do that you'll never get sutdents to work, they'll go to
other projects."
Need For Coordination
In light of the success of both AWARE and the
S.A. tutoring, it appears that coordinated planning for
the individual projects is essential. It becomes impossible
just to "want to tutor" or "want to help educate others"
about the inner city without some idea of direction.
Originally this coordination was to be
accomplished by the Community Involvement Board.
Students interested in working in the Inner City or in
community related projects were to go to the C. I. B.
and, from there, to the specific programs which
interested them. Unfortunately, such a OP suffered
from several difficulties.
One of the major problems was that few people
know exactly what the other organizations were trying
to accomplish. Only a few of the programs had specific
programs outlined.

Frosh Five Continue Winning Ways; Varsity B-Ballers
Handleman Stars as Highest Scorer Beat Weak F&M
By MIKE SHORE
The freshman basketball team has been
playing, and winning for the most part, with
great regularity since the News-Letter last came
out, winning four out of five games.
On Wednesday, January 15, the Baby Jays met the
undefeated squad from PMC Colleges, and failed to
change that status, losing by a score of 83-64. The PMC
team was big and fast, and our own team helped them
along with some inept play and bad shooting. PMC
jumped out to a 17-2 lead, and was never behind,
although at one time in the second half Hopkins caught
up to within 8. Gary Handleman was our leading scorer
with 22 points. The victory gave PMC a 12-0 record.
Jays Trip Terrors
In the next game they beat Western Maryland in
overtime, by the score of 87-85. The deciding two points
were made by John Lally from the free throw line with
two seconds left to play in the overtime period. Hal
Grinberg gave a spectacular performance that day,
making 24 points and taking 24 rebounds. Gary
Handleman, in his low game of the year, had 21.
After returning from semester break, the first

game was against the Towson State frosh, whom they
beat 103-89, thereby breaking an 8 game winning streak
for the 9-2 Towson Frosh. The leading scorers in this
game were Gary Handleman and Hal Grinberg with 26
apiece, and John Lally with 22. In addition coach
Barrette singled out George Apple for his exquisite ball
handling. The victory was dampened when Hal Grinberg
sprained his ankle late in the game.
Shooting Power
On Monday night the team met and conquered
Franklin & Marshall by 95-81. With Hal Grinberg ready
on the bench to play if needed, our team made up for a
disappointing defenses with their shooting power.
Handleman once again was high scorer with 37. John
Lally had 25, and George Apple 15 with 8 assists.
The shooting over the last 3 games has been really
good, averaging nearly 50% from the floor and 80% from
the line. Barrette hai promised to work on the defense.
The team's record now stands at 8-2. Gary
Handleman is averaging 28.1 points, some kind of high,
and John Lally has been coming on strong lately. They
play Ursinus Thursday, and a good Dickinson team on
Saturday, both away. Next Wednesday they will play
Loyola, at Loyola, at 3:30 in the afternoon.

By LARRY WOLK
The past two weeks were not prosperous ones for
the Hopkins Varsity Basketball team, as four losses and
one win brought their season record to a dismal 3-14.
Over intersession the Hoopsters dropped two
games. On February 1st, they gave Muhlenburg, last
year's league champs, a tough fight before bowing 79-69.
This was possibly the team's finest effort of the year.
John Judy started his first game as center, substituting
for the injured Jeff Thomas, and did a competent job.
Joe Loveland, started and also played a fine game until
sustaining an injury which will sideline him for the
remainder of the season.
On Tuesday Feb. 4, the Blue Jays were routed by
Towson State 99-67. The hot tigers shot an unbelievable
67% from the floor. Dave Rebovitch led the Hopkins
scoring with 18. Brian Berke and Sam Katz each had 14
points. Katz, playing primarily at the end of the game,
looked good on driving shots.
A tough Gettysburg team, which had beaten Navy
by four points, were the next team to defeat the Jays.
Brian Berke and Bill Piotrowski stood out as the quintet
put up a good fight before folding in the closing
minutes.
Jays Whipped
Saturday, February 8th, the
Hoopsters battled Drexel before
an enthusiastic home crowd. In
the see-saw game, Hopkins held
an early six point lead. The teams
went off at half-time tied 30-30.
Jeff Thomas, playing in his first
game since his injury sparked the
team during the second half. But
with 1:10 left, Drexel pulled
ahead, finally winning 60-56.
The lone victory came on
Monday, Feb. 10, against a weak
Franklin and Marshall team. The
game was a sloppy one, as both
teams appeared to be trying to
lose. The final score was 66-65.
Brian Berke lead the Hopkins
scoring-with 18. He was followed
by Dave Rebovitch who had 13.
Hal Thorne pumped in 10 points
and sunk some crucial baskets in
the fourth quarter to secure the
victory. Bill Piotrowski, who had
11 points, continued to show
;reat improvement in his shooting
and all around play.

WASHINGTON (CPS)—A preliminary
report of the National Commission on the
Causes and Prevention of Violence says that
young people provide the "thrust" of much of
the group protest and collective violence in the
ghetto, in the streets, and on the campuses.
"The key to much of the violence in our society
seems to lie with the young," says the report, which the
comission calls "only tentative, a first look, and subject
to revision."
The final report and recommendations are due in
the spring; investigation will continue till then: "It may
be with tomorrow's generation that much of the
emphasis of our studies and the national response should
lie."
Frustrated by System
The observation about youth is one of 10 "themes
of challenge" for Americans listed by the report.
Another notes that "violent protest today...has occurred
in part because protesters believe they cannot make their
demands felt effectively through normal, approved .
channels and that 'the system,' for whatever reasons, has
become unresponsive to them."
The report also mentions "additional
complications" that arise from "the high visibility" of
both violence and social inequities through the mass
media. The media may "aggravate" problems of
controlling violence, but they can also be "useful social
agents...helping to reduce levels of violence," the report
said.
The violence commission was established last June
by President Johnson "to undertake a penetrating isearch"
for the causes and prevention of disorder. Under
Chairman Milton S. Eisenhower, former President of
Hopkins, the commission set up task forces on historical
and comparative perspectives, individual acts of violence,
assassination, firearms, mass media,law enforcement and
group violence.

The study of group protest as a source of
collective violence focuses on anti-war and anti-draft
protest, campus unrest, black militancy, and official
response to such protest.
This task force particularly is interested in why
anti-war protest, which began peacefully, has recently
involved violent confrontations between demonstrators
and police.
"It is important to observe that the majority of
students have not been radicals or organizers of protest
imovements," the task force report says. "The impetus of
the anti-war movement seems to come basically from
young, middle-class, white liberals and radicals."
The commission is also studying recent unrest
among black students. A fact-finding team was recently
sent to San Francisco State College.
A few years ago the extremely small minority of
black students tended to be individualistic and mostly
politically inactive, the report notes. "The Black Power
Movement, however, coupled with substantial increases
in the number of black students, has offered some (of
them) a vehicle for giving collective expression to their
particular grievances."
Violence Will Stay
"The elimination of all violence in a free society is
impossible," the commission report concluded,"But the
better control of illegitimate violence in our democratic
society is an urgent imperative, and one within our
means to accomplish.
In its "themes and challenge," the report notes
that not all violence is illegitimate. "Indeed, a major
function of society is the organization and legitimization
of violence in the interest of maintaining society itself."
Some violence may be committed by persons with
deranged minds or abnormal biological make-up, but

experts agree that most is committed by normal people

Freshman ROTC enrollment is down 50 percent at

Iowa.
Elimination of credit was one of the early

Throughout this entire movie one
has the distinct impression that if
Ingmar Bergman loaded his camera with
color film the end product would still.

SHAME is a brilliant and powerful
movie, it is a very bleak and pessimistic
commentary on the human situation.
The action transpires around a

unexplained civil war. Their cottage

Perhaps pacifism is indisputable for him.
The soldiers themselves are
anonymous robots, whose faces are
either covered up or avoided by the
camera. Brief but sharp vignettes of
Gestapo-like brutality are recorded, and
they sink slowly into one's memory
rather than drench it with the gory
sensationalism that other anti-war films
seem to specialize in.

Bergman depicts the nightmare results

symbols, the most explicit of which are

The freshman basketball team has been
playing, and winning for the most part, with
great regularity since the News-Letter last came
out, winning four out of five games.

undefeated squad from PMC Colleges, and failed to

THE NEWS IN BRIEF
J.H.H. Gains Dean

.

Dr. Julius R. Krevans, professor of medicine at the
Johns Hopkins University of Medicine and
physician-in-chief at Baltimore City Hospitals, will
become dean for academic affairs at the school of
medicine as of July 1.
Dr. David E. Rogers, vice president for medicine
and dean of the medical faculty at Hopkins said Dr.
Krevans in the newly created post will give a point of
focus to all educational activities of the school
As a key member of Dr. Roger's administrative
staff, Dr. Krevans will assume broad responsibility for
the development of educational policies, including
post—doctoral education and curriculum development.
As one of the first tasks, Dr. Rogers said, Dr.
Krevans will pull together the output of the various
student and faculty groups working on the school of
medicines curriculum, in planning for comphrensive
changes for the future.
"We hope his appointment as dean for academic
affairs will enable Hopkins to take an imaginative new
approach to the whole spectrum of medical education,
from the first year of college through the total period of
post-doctoral study," said Dean Rogers.

WHO Selects .111H
The Johns Hopkins Hospital has been selected by
the United Nation's World Health Organization as the
only U.S. hospital to aprticipate as a collaborating center
in a WHO clinical study of breast cancer which will begin
this year.
Dr. Edward F. Lewison, chief of the Hospital's
breast cancer clinic, will direct Hopkins involvement in
the project. He recently returned from WHO
headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland, where he was
elected vice-chairman of the international breast cancer
group.
The Johns Hopkins School of Medicine has also
been endowed $625,000 by the Independent Order of
Odd Fellows which has established a professorship in eye
research. The professor, Dr. Arthur M. Silverstein, is
presently studying part time on the basic reasons why
tissue transplants are rejected by the recipient.
In a final development, the Hopkins Hospital has
announced that it is establishing with the March of
Dimes the nation's first major center to detect inherited
defects in a baby before birth. The one year grant to the
Hospital by the March of Dimes totaling $20,000 will
begin in March. "The scientific capability now exists for
the detection of defects or the reassurance of normality
in a sizeable number of genetic abnormalities," declared
the program head.

Role Proposed
Governor Mandel recently said he favored _a move
by University of Maryland students for greater
representation on their Board of Regents.
But at the same time, the Governor opposed giving
a student member of the governing board a vote or voice
in policy decisions. He told newsmen, "1 don't see
anything wrong with a representative of the student
body sitting on the board, not as a participating member
with the right to vote, but in some advisory capacity."
The student government has been pushing for
greater participation in university affairs, but so far has
been rebuffed by Dr. Wilson Elkins, the university
president and by the regents in attempts to give the
student body a policy vote..
"I think they should be entitled to participate in
the affairs of the university as much as possible," Mr.
Mandel explained. "But 1 think the university should be
run by the people whose job it is." Although he also
took a stand against direct student demands, he says the
board should listen to them. Mandel, a graduate of the
University of Maryland, has the power to appoint the
regents.

Half-Fare Dropped
The Civil Aeronautics Board (CAB) has ruled that
half-fare stand-by tickets for students should be
eliminated.
Representative Arnold Olsen (D. Mont.) charged
that elimination of airline youth fares would "encourage
thousands of young people to resume the illegal and
dangerous practice of hitch hiking or to attempt long,
exhausting automobile trips, frequently in unsafe

vehicles." He argued that no one would benefit from a
discontinuation of youth fares.
Urging continued emphasis on education, Olsen
cited the air fare as "an important factor in easing the
travel burden of thousands of college students." Olsen
asserted that "strict, imprudent application of the
non-discrimination ruling would threaten half-fare
tickets for youngsters between 2, and 12 years of age
(reservations can be made for such tickets), for military
personnel, and several other special fare categories now
properly and prudently provided by the airlines."
The CAB ruling, written by Examiner Arthur S.
Present, judged the special fare discriminatory to adult
passengers. If upheld by the five-member Board, youth
fares will be dropped in 30 days. In a letter to CAB
Chairman John H. Crooker, Olsen asked that the
Tuesday decision be reviewed and rescinded.

College Reforms Set
More than 40 bills averaging over two a day were
introduced last month in the California legislature all
aimed at denying to various extents the freedom of state
college administrators or students.
0ne bil1 presented would require a college
president to dismiss a faculty member or student who
took part in campus disruption. Another would shorten
the 16-year term for the 15 appointive regents of the
University of California. A third proposal would remove
the ex offico regents who hold office because of their
elective position.
State Senator, John Schimitz of Orange County, a
John Birch Society member,said to his constituents in a
newsletter last week, "Let's call their bluff." He would
close colleges where disruptions occur.
Meanwhile, at San Francisco State, President S.I.
Hayakawa, offered last week to rehire the 199 striking
teachers when the college hopes to reopen on February
17.
Dr. Hayakawa praised Governor Ronald Reagan's
action in designating the University of California
Berkeley campus as an emergency disaster area and
dispatching State highway patrolmen there to help keep
order. The Acting President said that most academic
safeguards were devised during the "era of Senator
Joseph McCarthy." Now the attacks to academic
freedom are coming from within, from the left, and
from the minorities below, he said.

Grades Ruin Prof
Dr. Arthur DuPre, who gave most of his
mathematics students A's, is apparently flunking out of
Wright State University.
The 3rd year university assistant professor from
Spartanburg, S.C., gave the A grades for the autumn
quarter to 101 of the 1 1 1 students in his algebra and
calculus classes. "Mathematics," he explained, "is
incestuously feeding upon itself and not getting any new
ideas or opinions which would disturb the established
authority."
He said the high grades—he gave 10 "incompletes"
to students who failed to take the final exam—was more
than a protest against the grading system. "I was telling
my students they had earned their A's by my standards
and criteria," he said. "1 had never been so impressed in
my life."
The department chairman, Carl C. Maneri, has
asked for Dr. DuPre's resignation in writing.

Racism, American foreign policy in Latin
America and Vietnam, urban problems, the new
Congress and upcoming legislation are among
the issues to be discussed at a conference for
students and faculty to be held at Homewood
on Saturday, February 15.
The theme of the one-day conference, which is
being sponsored by the College Program of fly; American
Friends Service Committee, Middle Atlantic Region, is
"Shall We Build a Desert and Call It Peace?".
Dr. Arthur I. Waskow, Resident Fellow at the
Institute for Policy Studies, Washington, D.C., is slated
to deliver the keynote address, "The Next Thirty Years
of American History." Waskow, a political activist and
theoretician, is the author of several books and articles
on national defense, racial conflict and the politics of
the 1960's and served as a delegate to the 1968
Democratic National Convention.

been scheduled so that each conference participant will
be able to attend two.
Tran Van Dinh, a journalist, and the Republic of
Vietnam's former acting ambassador to the United
States, will lead a seminar entitled "Can Future
Vietnams be Avoided?".
U.S. policy in Latin America will be examined in a
seminar given by David Morris, Fellow at the Institute
for Policy Studies and instructor at Federal City College.
"Race, Class, Sex: Is Anyone Out There
Healthy?", a seminar on various conflicting American
attitudes and values, will be given by Martin
Oppenheimer, Chairman of the Department of
Sociology/Anthropology at Lincoln University.
Nonviolent direct action in social change will be
discussed in a seminar led by Bob Levering of the
Friends Service Committee, Philadelphia.
"The City as Battleground," an analysis of
Baltimore's economic and social problems and its power
structure, will be offered by Gren Whitman of the
Baltimore Peace Action Center.
The new Congress and upcoming legislation, such
as the "black capitalism" bill, will be examined by Ed
Anderson, Associate Secretary for Human Rights of the
Friends Committee on National Legislation.
The topic, "Can We Humanize the University in a
Business Society?" will be discussed by Lee Lowenfish
of the Goucher History Dept., Steve Mann, Assistant
Professor of Education at Hopkins, and a panel of
students from area colleges.
The conference is open to all interested college
students and faculty in the Baltimore area. The cost is
$2.00. Further information may be obtained from the
AFSC office at 319 East 25th St., 467-9100.

By ART LE'VINE

The first issue of the Odyssey, a new
campus newspaper, will appear soon after the
end of rush.
The first issue of approximately six New York
Times-size pages will be generally concerned with the
"social system" at Johns Hopkins. It will include
columns from representatives of major campus
organizations, feature articles, news, and photographs.
According to the Editor, Bill Nordheim, as many interest
groups as possible will be represented in the new paper.
Furthermore, letters are out to 31 other colleges asking
them to write on the social functions of their campuses.
In an interview, Nordheim stated that the Odyssey
was not intended to be in competition with the
News-Letter. He felt, however, that the News-Letter
doesn't fulfill its obligation as a campus newspaper. The
Odyssey is an attempt to do something about the lack of
community on campus, Nordheim said.
Although the paper has received $800 from the
S.A.C., probably only two issues of the Odyssey will
appear this year, due to the lack of advertising revenue
so far. Nordheim further noted that Business Manager
John Ullman was having trouble raising ad revenue
because of the newness of the paper. Nordheim was,
however, optimistic about next year's prospects for the
Odyssey. "Personally," he said. "I think it could be a
very good contribution to the campus."
Some of the major interests represented by
columns will be: The IFC, S.D.S., Black Student Union,
Lincoln Gordon, The Student Council, Young
Democrats, The Student Association, and Bill
McQueeney.
The final staff meeting will be held Feb. 16, and
anyone wishing to help or contribute is urged to contact
Bill Nordheim, 206 Hollander or Box 2283.
